Legal Citation Types - Categories of Compliance

What Are Citation Types?

Citation Types organize legal requirements by jurisdiction and scope. They help you quickly identify which laws apply to your specific documents.

Six Standard Citation Types

Federal Regulations

Scope: Nationwide requirements

Examples: IRS tax records, OSHA safety logs, FLSA payroll

When to Use: Documents governed by federal agencies

State Laws

Scope: State-specific requirements

Examples: California personnel records, state tax documents

When to Use: Multi-state operations with varying laws

County Ordinances

Scope: County-level regulations

Examples: Building permits, zoning records

When to Use: Local government compliance

City Codes

Scope: Municipal requirements

Examples: Business licenses, health permits

When to Use: City-specific documentation

Industry Standards

Scope: Industry-specific regulations

Examples: HIPAA (healthcare), SOX (financial), FDA

When to Use: Vertical-specific compliance

Corporate Policies

Scope: Internal company requirements

Examples: HR policies, contract standards

When to Use: Beyond legal minimums

Understanding Retention Periods

Important: When multiple citations apply, always use the LONGEST retention period to ensure compliance with all applicable laws.

Example: Payroll Records

Consider payroll documents with multiple requirements:

  • FLSA: 3 years (federal minimum)
  • IRS: 7 years (tax audit protection)
  • State Law: May vary (e.g., California = 7 years)

Result: Retain for 7 years to satisfy all requirements.

Record Series Codes - O'Neil Stratus Standard

Record Series - Simplifying Compliance Management

What Is a Record Series?

A Record Series groups related documents that share:

  • Common legal citations
  • Same retention period
  • Identical disposition method
  • Similar business purpose
Key Benefit: Assign one Record Series instead of manually selecting multiple citations for each container - citations and retention auto-populate!

Pre-Loaded Record Series Examples

O'Neil Stratus Naming Convention

Record Series codes follow industry-standard O'Neil Stratus format:

Format: [CATEGORY]-[SUBCATEGORY] or [PREFIX]-[NUMBER]

Examples:
  HR-PRSNL    = Human Resources - Personnel
  TAX-PYRL    = Tax - Payroll
  GS3011-156  = General Schedule 3011, Item 156
  LEGAL-CNTR  = Legal - Contracts

Disposition Methods - End of Retention Handling

Disposition Methods - Proper Document Destruction

What Is a Disposition Method?

A Disposition Method defines how records are handled when they reach the end of their retention period.

Critical: Improper disposition can result in data breaches, regulatory violations, and loss of legal protection. Always follow approved methods.

Six Standard Disposition Methods

üîí Shred (NAID Certificate Required)

Use For: Confidential documents, PII, financial records

Process: Cross-cut shredding with NAID AAA certification

Certificate: Yes - destruction certificate issued

Examples: Tax records, personnel files, medical records

üî• Incinerate (NAID Certificate Required)

Use For: Highly sensitive documents requiring complete destruction

Process: Industrial incineration with witness verification

Certificate: Yes - destruction certificate issued

Examples: Classified documents, proprietary information

‚ôªÔ∏è Recycle (No Certificate)

Use For: Non-confidential documents

Process: Standard paper recycling

Certificate: No

Examples: General correspondence, public notices

üì§ Transfer Ownership

Use For: Records transferred to another party

Process: Documented transfer with chain of custody

Certificate: No (transfer receipt instead)

Examples: Client files returned, archives donated

üèõÔ∏è Archive (Permanent)

Use For: Permanent records with historical value

Process: Long-term storage with preservation measures

Certificate: No

Examples: Corporate charter, board minutes, patents

‚è∏Ô∏è Review Required

Use For: Records requiring case-by-case evaluation

Process: Manual review before disposition decision

Certificate: Depends on final decision

Examples: Legal contracts, litigation holds

NAID AAA Certification

What Is NAID AAA?

National Association for Information Destruction - AAA Certification is the gold standard for secure document destruction.

Certification Requirements:
  • Annual on-site audits by independent inspectors
  • Employee background checks and training
  • Secure chain of custody procedures
  • Witnessed destruction processes
  • Tamper-evident containers
  • Documented destruction certificates
Certificate of Destruction Includes:
  • Date and time of destruction
  • Method used (shred/incinerate)
  • Container/box identifiers
  • Witness signatures
  • NAID facility certification number

Choosing the Right Disposition Method

Document Sensitivity Recommended Method Reason
Contains PII (SSN, financial data) Shred with NAID cert Legal liability, HIPAA/GLBA compliance
Classified/Trade secrets Incinerate with NAID cert Maximum security, complete destruction
General business records Shred or Recycle Industry best practice
Public information Recycle Environmentally responsible
Historical significance Archive (Permanent) Organizational memory
Ongoing litigation Review Required Legal hold requirements
Legal Requirement: When in doubt, always choose the more secure option. Over-protecting data is better than under-protecting it.

Troubleshooting Common Issues

Issue: Citations don't auto-populate when selecting Record Series

Cause: Record Series may not have citations linked

Solution:

  1. Open Record Series form
  2. Check "Legal Citations" field
  3. Add missing citations
  4. Save and test again
Issue: Retention period incorrect

Cause: Multiple citations with different retention periods

Solution:

  1. Check all linked citations
  2. Verify retention years for each
  3. System should use longest period - if not, report bug
  4. Can override manually if needed
Issue: Can't create custom Record Series

Cause: Insufficient permissions

Solution:

  1. Verify you have "Records User" security group
  2. Only Users can create Record Series (not Citation Types)
  3. Contact administrator to grant access
